Week Update Cyber security

By Cybervie-Cyber Security Services


By Cybervie-Cyber Security Services

    
    
    Read this article on LinkedIn to join the conversation
Read on LinkedIn
https://www.linkedin.com/comm/pulse/phishing-email-analysis-cybervie-com-coo3f?lipi=urn%3Ali%3Apage%3Aemail_email_series_follow_newsletter_01%3BsH%2F72cvXQkuvM11CHG4KDA%3D%3D&midToken=AQEL2poUgT6org&midSig=24uiE6KMYN0rU1&trk=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-null-0-read_more_banner_cta_&trkEmail=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-null-0-read_more_banner_cta_-null-9atbpc~mdo0f1a2~1p-null-null&eid=9atbpc-mdo0f1a2-1p&otpToken=MTcwMzFjZTMxNzI3YzBjN2IyMjQwNGVkNDMxZGUwYjI4ZWM4ZDc0MDkwYTc4ZTYxNzVjMTA2NmI0ZTVhNTRmN2YzZDNkZjliNzNkN2I4ZGU2M2Y5ZmQ4NDhmMTY1YjJmOTNiNTRjNGMwYmRhYTIyYTlmZTFhYiwxLDE%3D
  
Overview Email Body Analysis Investigation Process Email Header Analysis Key Fields SPF(Sender Policy Framework) DKIM(Domain Keys Identified Mail) DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance) Mail User Agent (MUA) Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) Other Fields Manual Investigation Process Automate Investigation Process Reference Tools Overview Phishing is a common form of cyber attack that uses emails to trick victims into providing sensitive information or installing malware. It is a major threat to businesses and individuals alike, and it is crucial to be able to detect and analyze phishing emails to prevent them from causing harm. In this blog post, we will discuss the step-by-step process of phishing email analysis to help you detect and prevent these attacks. We can divide this analysis into two parts one would Email Body Analysis and Email Header Analysis. Email Body Analysis In this step, we will examine the content of the email. Look for signs that the email might be a phishing attempt, such as urgent requests for personal or financial information, requests for passwords or account numbers, or requests to download attachments, or request to click on the link. Also, pay attention to the sender's email address and the sender's domain name, as phishing emails often use fake addresses, domains that are similar to those of legitimate organizations, and sometimes use spoofed domains. The email body is the main content area of an email message and it can contain various types of information. Some of the information that can be observed in the email body include: Text content: The main text of the message, which can include information about the sender, recipient, subject matter, and other details. Image: Embedded images or graphics that are included in the message. Hyperlinks: Links to websites or other resources that are included in the message. Attachments: Files or other attachments that are included with the message. HTML formatting: Formatting elements such as font styles, colors, and background images that are used to enhance the visual appearance of the message. Scripts: Scripts or code that can run within the message, such as JavaScript or VBScript. Metadata: Information about the structure and formatting of the message, such as character encoding, line breaks, and white space. Will try to understand this in detail with a real-time phishing email. Investigation Process: Examine the sender domain, which is "cybervie.com", using an open-source intelligence tool such as Virus Total. The domain appears to be safe, so we can proceed to the next step. The email originated from "Cybervie Admin" but in the greeting it was addressed as "Microsoft Financer", raising suspicion. The email's content states that an account has been locked but does not specify which account, and it does not address anyone directly. The email contains a hyperlink, and upon hovering the mouse over it, the actual link can be viewed in the browser's left corner. The link in question is "hxxps://amfcu5x.web.app/". Utilizing Virus Total could yield valuable information. Many security vendors flagged this as Phishing. Note: It is not necessary that you may follow the same investigation steps Phishing emails crafted by attackers may not follow the same method, making it sometimes challenging to identify them just by examining their body content. In this case, Email Header Analysis will useful. Email Header Analysis The next step is to analyze the email headers. This is the information that is contained in the email message that is not visible to the recipient. The headers contain important information such as the sender's IP address, the email server used to send the message, and the routing information for the email. Before proceeding with email header analysis, let's familiarize ourselves with the key parameters that are present in the headers. Key Fields We will delve into the crucial key parameters found in email headers that can assist us in identifying phishing emails. 1.SPF(Sender Policy Framework) SPF defines a process by which an organization can specify which server(s) are authorized to send emails on its behalf. If an email fails an SPF check, it may indicate that it is spam. In simple terms, an SPF record is a list of authorized email servers for a particular domain. When an email is received, the recipient's email server checks the SPF record for the domain of the sender's email address. If the server that sent the email is not on the list of authorized servers, the email may be marked as spam or rejected entirely. 2.DKIM(Domain Keys Identified Mail) It Provides a cryptographic method of verifying a received email actually originated from the sending domain. We can use this to detect forged senders. Here is how DKIM works: The sending server generates a digital signature for the message using a private key. The signature is added to the header of the message as a DKIM signature. When the email is received, the recipient's email server retrieves the public key associated with the domain of the sender's email address. The recipient's email server uses the public key to verify the authenticity of the digital signature. If the digital signature is valid, the email server knows that the message has not been altered or modified in transit and that it was actually sent by the domain it claims to be sent from. 3.DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance) It is an email authentication protocol that helps prevent email spoofing and ensures the authenticity of an email message. It builds on top of the existing SPF (Sender Policy Framework) and DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail) protocols and provides a mechanism for recipient email servers to verify the authenticity of an incoming email message. It works by allowing domain owners to publish a policy in their DNS record specifying how recipient email servers should handle incoming emails that fail SPF or DKIM validation. The recipient's email server will then check the incoming email against this policy and follow the instructions to reject, mark as spam, or deliver the email. DMARC also provides a reporting mechanism for domain owners to receive feedback and improve their email authentication. 4.Mail User Agent (MUA) client application running on your computer that is used to send and receive email. 5.Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) accepts messages from a sender and routes them along to their destinations. 6.Other Fields These are the additional fields present in email headers that will be utilized for investigative purposes. Message-ID Received In-Reply-To References Trace fields Return Path Content-Length X-originating-IP Reply-to path MIME boundary delimiters RFS-defined headers fields Note: The email headers are separate from the email body and are not visible by default. To access the headers, certain steps must be taken to retrieve them from the received email. Please find the reference link below that outlines how to obtain headers from various email service providers. Will try to understand this in detail with the above phishing email. This is what Email Header would look like. Manual Investigation Process: We will begin our investigation by analyzing the return-path. In most phishing email cases, the "from" address and the “return-path” are different, but in our case, they are the same. Then will proceed with analyzing Received Field, The topmost "Received" field shows the nearest server to the destination in the email path. The bottommost "Received" field is closest to the email's source. The number of "Received" fields depends on the MTA agents the email passed through from source to destination. We will see that an email might contain multiple received headers. This means that this email has passed through multiple servers (internal and external) before reaching us. The lack of DKIM and DMARC entries in the header suggests that the receiver's mail server may not have set up these configurations. The Received-SPF field is a "softfail", indicating that the cybervie domain has been spoofed by the attacker, confirming that this is a spoofed email. Automate Investigation Process: Copy the Mail headers in a Clip Board Using any open-source header analysis, we preferred Mxtoolbox. Past the header and click on Analyze button. Probable you may get analysis result in a couple of minutes. Manual analysis of email headers can give the same results, but using a graphical representation can simplify and speed up the analysis process. Reference Tools Tools that can be used to analyze phishing emails, but it is not limited to. MxToolBox Gaijin WhatismyIP MailHeader Google PhishTank IPvoid
Keep reading on LinkedIn
https://www.linkedin.com/comm/pulse/phishing-email-analysis-cybervie-com-coo3f?lipi=urn%3Ali%3Apage%3Aemail_email_series_follow_newsletter_01%3BsH%2F72cvXQkuvM11CHG4KDA%3D%3D&midToken=AQEL2poUgT6org&midSig=24uiE6KMYN0rU1&trk=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-newsletter_content_preview_text-0-readmore_button_&trkEmail=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-newsletter_content_preview_text-0-readmore_button_-null-9atbpc~mdo0f1a2~1p-null-null&eid=9atbpc-mdo0f1a2-1p&otpToken=MTcwMzFjZTMxNzI3YzBjN2IyMjQwNGVkNDMxZGUwYjI4ZWM4ZDc0MDkwYTc4ZTYxNzVjMTA2NmI0ZTVhNTRmN2YzZDNkZjliNzNkN2I4ZGU2M2Y5ZmQ4NDhmMTY1YjJmOTNiNTRjNGMwYmRhYTIyYTlmZTFhYiwxLDE%3D

Week Update Cyber security

By Cybervie-Cyber Security Services

By Cybervie-Cyber Security Services

Read this article on LinkedIn to join the conversation
Read on LinkedIn
https://www.linkedin.com/comm/pulse/phishing-email-analysis-cybervie-com-coo3f?lipi=urn%3Ali%3Apage%3Aemail_email_series_follow_newsletter_01%3BsH%2F72cvXQkuvM11CHG4KDA%3D%3D&midToken=AQEL2poUgT6org&midSig=24uiE6KMYN0rU1&trk=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-null-0-read_more_banner_cta_&trkEmail=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-null-0-read_more_banner_cta_-null-9atbpc~mdo0f1a2~1p-null-null&eid=9atbpc-mdo0f1a2-1p&otpToken=MTcwMzFjZTMxNzI3YzBjN2IyMjQwNGVkNDMxZGUwYjI4ZWM4ZDc0MDkwYTc4ZTYxNzVjMTA2NmI0ZTVhNTRmN2YzZDNkZjliNzNkN2I4ZGU2M2Y5ZmQ4NDhmMTY1YjJmOTNiNTRjNGMwYmRhYTIyYTlmZTFhYiwxLDE%3D

Overview Email Body Analysis Investigation Process Email Header Analysis Key Fields SPF(Sender Policy Framework) DKIM(Domain Keys Identified Mail) DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance) Mail User Agent (MUA) Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) Other Fields Manual Investigation Process Automate Investigation Process Reference Tools Overview Phishing is a common form of cyber attack that uses emails to trick victims into providing sensitive information or installing malware. It is a major threat to businesses and individuals alike, and it is crucial to be able to detect and analyze phishing emails to prevent them from causing harm. In this blog post, we will discuss the step-by-step process of phishing email analysis to help you detect and prevent these attacks. We can divide this analysis into two parts one would Email Body Analysis and Email Header Analysis. Email Body Analysis In this step, we will examine the content of the email. Look for signs that the email might be a phishing attempt, such as urgent requests for personal or financial information, requests for passwords or account numbers, or requests to download attachments, or request to click on the link. Also, pay attention to the sender's email address and the sender's domain name, as phishing emails often use fake addresses, domains that are similar to those of legitimate organizations, and sometimes use spoofed domains. The email body is the main content area of an email message and it can contain various types of information. Some of the information that can be observed in the email body include: Text content: The main text of the message, which can include information about the sender, recipient, subject matter, and other details. Image: Embedded images or graphics that are included in the message. Hyperlinks: Links to websites or other resources that are included in the message. Attachments: Files or other attachments that are included with the message. HTML formatting: Formatting elements such as font styles, colors, and background images that are used to enhance the visual appearance of the message. Scripts: Scripts or code that can run within the message, such as JavaScript or VBScript. Metadata: Information about the structure and formatting of the message, such as character encoding, line breaks, and white space. Will try to understand this in detail with a real-time phishing email. Investigation Process: Examine the sender domain, which is "cybervie.com", using an open-source intelligence tool such as Virus Total. The domain appears to be safe, so we can proceed to the next step. The email originated from "Cybervie Admin" but in the greeting it was addressed as "Microsoft Financer", raising suspicion. The email's content states that an account has been locked but does not specify which account, and it does not address anyone directly. The email contains a hyperlink, and upon hovering the mouse over it, the actual link can be viewed in the browser's left corner. The link in question is "hxxps://amfcu5x.web.app/". Utilizing Virus Total could yield valuable information. Many security vendors flagged this as Phishing. Note: It is not necessary that you may follow the same investigation steps Phishing emails crafted by attackers may not follow the same method, making it sometimes challenging to identify them just by examining their body content. In this case, Email Header Analysis will useful. Email Header Analysis The next step is to analyze the email headers. This is the information that is contained in the email message that is not visible to the recipient. The headers contain important information such as the sender's IP address, the email server used to send the message, and the routing information for the email. Before proceeding with email header analysis, let's familiarize ourselves with the key parameters that are present in the headers. Key Fields We will delve into the crucial key parameters found in email headers that can assist us in identifying phishing emails. 1.SPF(Sender Policy Framework) SPF defines a process by which an organization can specify which server(s) are authorized to send emails on its behalf. If an email fails an SPF check, it may indicate that it is spam. In simple terms, an SPF record is a list of authorized email servers for a particular domain. When an email is received, the recipient's email server checks the SPF record for the domain of the sender's email address. If the server that sent the email is not on the list of authorized servers, the email may be marked as spam or rejected entirely. 2.DKIM(Domain Keys Identified Mail) It Provides a cryptographic method of verifying a received email actually originated from the sending domain. We can use this to detect forged senders. Here is how DKIM works: The sending server generates a digital signature for the message using a private key. The signature is added to the header of the message as a DKIM signature. When the email is received, the recipient's email server retrieves the public key associated with the domain of the sender's email address. The recipient's email server uses the public key to verify the authenticity of the digital signature. If the digital signature is valid, the email server knows that the message has not been altered or modified in transit and that it was actually sent by the domain it claims to be sent from. 3.DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance) It is an email authentication protocol that helps prevent email spoofing and ensures the authenticity of an email message. It builds on top of the existing SPF (Sender Policy Framework) and DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail) protocols and provides a mechanism for recipient email servers to verify the authenticity of an incoming email message. It works by allowing domain owners to publish a policy in their DNS record specifying how recipient email servers should handle incoming emails that fail SPF or DKIM validation. The recipient's email server will then check the incoming email against this policy and follow the instructions to reject, mark as spam, or deliver the email. DMARC also provides a reporting mechanism for domain owners to receive feedback and improve their email authentication. 4.Mail User Agent (MUA) client application running on your computer that is used to send and receive email. 5.Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) accepts messages from a sender and routes them along to their destinations. 6.Other Fields These are the additional fields present in email headers that will be utilized for investigative purposes. Message-ID Received In-Reply-To References Trace fields Return Path Content-Length X-originating-IP Reply-to path MIME boundary delimiters RFS-defined headers fields Note: The email headers are separate from the email body and are not visible by default. To access the headers, certain steps must be taken to retrieve them from the received email. Please find the reference link below that outlines how to obtain headers from various email service providers. Will try to understand this in detail with the above phishing email. This is what Email Header would look like. Manual Investigation Process: We will begin our investigation by analyzing the return-path. In most phishing email cases, the "from" address and the “return-path” are different, but in our case, they are the same. Then will proceed with analyzing Received Field, The topmost "Received" field shows the nearest server to the destination in the email path. The bottommost "Received" field is closest to the email's source. The number of "Received" fields depends on the MTA agents the email passed through from source to destination. We will see that an email might contain multiple received headers. This means that this email has passed through multiple servers (internal and external) before reaching us. The lack of DKIM and DMARC entries in the header suggests that the receiver's mail server may not have set up these configurations. The Received-SPF field is a "softfail", indicating that the cybervie domain has been spoofed by the attacker, confirming that this is a spoofed email. Automate Investigation Process: Copy the Mail headers in a Clip Board Using any open-source header analysis, we preferred Mxtoolbox. Past the header and click on Analyze button. Probable you may get analysis result in a couple of minutes. Manual analysis of email headers can give the same results, but using a graphical representation can simplify and speed up the analysis process. Reference Tools Tools that can be used to analyze phishing emails, but it is not limited to. MxToolBox Gaijin WhatismyIP MailHeader Google PhishTank IPvoid

Wipro Recruitment 2025 | Production Specialist – L1 | Chennai

Fresher Jobs
Read this article on LinkedIn to join the conversation
Read on LinkedIn

Wipro Limited is inviting applications for the role of Production Specialist – L1 at its Chennai location. This opportunity is ideal for professionals with 1–3 years of experience in technical support or production operations and looking to grow their career in a globally recognized tech organization.

This newsletter brings you a verified, professional job opening that aligns with LinkedIn’s safe sharing policies and offers value to our professional community.

About Wipro

Wipro Limited (NYSE: WIT, BSE: 507685, NSE: WIPRO) is a leading global technology services and consulting company. With over 230,000 employees across 65+ countries, Wipro delivers strategic solutions in consulting, design, engineering, and digital operations. It is consistently ranked among the top employers globally.

Job Details

  • Job Title: Production Specialist – L1
  • Company: Wipro Limited
  • Experience Required: 1–3 Years
  • Qualification: B.E / B.Tech
  • Job Location: Chennai
  • Salary: Best in Industry
  • Application Mode: Online

Key Responsibilities

  • Address technical queries and support requests via email/phone.
  • Document problem-solving steps and resolutions.
  • Maintain internal knowledge resources and databases.
  • Follow SLA guidelines and escalate issues when necessary.
  • Participate in training programs to stay updated on tools and processes.
  • Deliver client-centric support to enhance overall satisfaction.

Who Should Apply?

  • Candidates with 1–3 years of experience in tech support, customer support, or L1 production support.
  • Strong communicators with a solution-oriented mindset.

Fresher Jobs Opportunities

By Fresher Jobs

By Fresher Jobs

Read this article on LinkedIn to join the conversation
Read on LinkedIn
https://www.linkedin.com/comm/pulse/wipro-recruitment-2025-production-specialist-l1-chennai-fresher-job-qiaef?lipi=urn%3Ali%3Apage%3Aemail_email_series_follow_newsletter_01%3BiNrzr4H1RzCesH46Deo0kA%3D%3D&midToken=AQEL2poUgT6org&midSig=24uiE6KMYN0rU1&trk=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-null-0-read_more_banner_cta_&trkEmail=eml-email_series_follow_newsletter_01-null-0-read_more_banner_cta_-null-9atbpc~mdo0f1a1~km-null-null&eid=9atbpc-mdo0f1a1-km&otpToken=MTcwMzFjZTMxNzI3YzBjN2IyMjQwNGVkNDMxZGUwYjI4ZWM4ZDc0MDkwYTk4ZTYxNzVjMTA2NmI0ZTVhNTRmN2YzZDNkZmE3NzdkNWMxZDQwMWY4YzBjYjZkNjdiYzI5MmVhZjM3OWQxYmI2NDczOTI0ZjA2NSwxLDE%3D

Wipro Limited is inviting applications for the role of Production Specialist – L1 at its Chennai location. This opportunity is ideal for professionals with 1–3 years of experience in technical support or production operations and looking to grow their career in a globally recognized tech organization. This newsletter brings you a verified, professional job opening that aligns with LinkedIn’s safe sharing policies and offers value to our professional community. About Wipro Wipro Limited (NYSE: WIT, BSE: 507685, NSE: WIPRO) is a leading global technology services and consulting company. With over 230,000 employees across 65+ countries, Wipro delivers strategic solutions in consulting, design, engineering, and digital operations. It is consistently ranked among the top employers globally. Job Details Job Title: Production Specialist – L1 Company: Wipro Limited Experience Required: 1–3 Years Qualification: B.E / B.Tech Job Location: Chennai Salary: Best in Industry Application Mode: Online Key Responsibilities Address technical queries and support requests via email/phone. Document problem-solving steps and resolutions. Maintain internal knowledge resources and databases. Follow SLA guidelines and escalate issues when necessary. Participate in training programs to stay updated on tools and processes. Deliver client-centric support to enhance overall satisfaction. Who Should Apply? Candidates with 1–3 years of experience in tech support, customer support, or L1 production support. Strong communicators with a solution-oriented mindset. Willingness to work in a fast-paced service environment. Why Consider Wipro? Work for one of the most respected tech brands in the world. Be part of digital transformation projects at a global scale. Opportunity to learn and grow within a structured career path. Exposure to international clients and cross-functional teams. How to Apply? Full Details: https://quickfresherjobs.in/wipro-recruitment-2025-hiring-for-production-specialist-l1-apply-now/

The Ken Daily
A personalised introduction to our latest stories, newsletters, and podcasts

How EY became rivals’ feeding ground for tech consultants

The Ken
Read this article on LinkedIn to join the conversation
Read on LinkedIn

The door is revolving at EY.

In the Big Four universe, partners leave routinely, but the frequency at which it’s happening at the audit-and-consulting major, it’s nothing close to routine.

Dubbing it normal “attrition”, even “healthy” to an extent, an EY spokesperson said the firm hired 50 partners in just one year, and it has overall hired more than it has lost.

That may be true, but to arrest the departures and their impact, EY increased the notice period for partners leaving the firm from six to nine months earlier this year.

As the lines between the Big Four, MBB, IT-services (and now BPO with Capgemini acquiring WNS), and boutique tech-consulting firms blur, there’s a scramble to become a one-stop shop and deliver everything in the shortest possible time.

In all this, tech consulting becomes a pressure point, and at EY, the highest revenue-earner division, it is also the fastest revolving door. Senior partners are leaving structural mismatches behind them. As one former partner summarised to Debanjali Biswas , writer of today’s story, “You need to play chess with these industry veterans. Instead, they [EY] are playing Chinese checkers.”

Do check out the story here: How EY became rivals’ feeding ground for tech consultants

While I have your attention… AI providers need to constantly adapt or become obsolete. This is part of a bigger shakeup in the way products are built, as well as how product managers, designers, engineers, and others work together.

It was once en vogue to move fast and break things, but it’s now necessary to ship, ship, ship—and ensure everything that goes live is ready for real-world users.

...
Keep reading on LinkedIn
This email was intended for Mayank Agrawal (IESEG, Paris | HPAIR AFCON'24 | Ex ATGL | GL G'25 | VIT V'20)

The door is revolving at EY. In the Big Four universe, partners leave routinely, but the frequency at which it’s happening at the audit-and-consulting major, it’s nothing close to routine. Dubbing it normal “attrition”, even “healthy” to an extent, an EY spokesperson said the firm hired 50 partners in just one year, and it has overall hired more than it has lost. That may be true, but to arrest the departures and their impact, EY increased the notice period for partners leaving the firm from six to nine months earlier this year. As the lines between the Big Four, MBB, IT-services (and now BPO with Capgemini acquiring WNS), and boutique tech-consulting firms blur, there’s a scramble to become a one-stop shop and deliver everything in the shortest possible time. In all this, tech consulting becomes a pressure point, and at EY, the highest revenue-earner division, it is also the fastest revolving door. Senior partners are leaving structural mismatches behind them. As one former partner summarised to Debanjali Biswas, writer of today’s story, “You need to play chess with these industry veterans. Instead, they [EY] are playing Chinese checkers.” Do check out the story here: How EY became rivals’ feeding ground for tech consultants While I have your attention… AI providers need to constantly adapt or become obsolete. This is part of a bigger shakeup in the way products are built, as well as how product managers, designers, engineers, and others work together. It was once en vogue to move fast and break things, but it’s now necessary to ship, ship, ship—and ensure everything that goes live is ready for real-world users. The organisation, methodologies, and power dynamics of product teams are all changing. If that intrigues you, terrifies you, or excites you, come be part of The Ken’s next event on 26 July. We’ll hear from practitioners who are at the forefront of these transformations, and find out what they’re doing to stay ahead of the curve. Join us in person if you’re in Bengaluru, or live stream the event if you’re anywhere else. Book your tickets here. Also from our newsroom today: Shein is back. Where does that leave its clones?—Newme rose to prominence after Shein was booted out of the Indian market, and it did that by essentially replicating the Shein playbook. Now, it’s got to compete against the original [Read here] FMCG giants are caught in a spice war. MTR’s owner beat them to it years ago—Orkla’s IPO is up against a regionally-fragmented spice market, where each state has its own unique spice blends [Listen here] That's all for now. See you tomorrow. — Seema Singh, Editor

output.title: A Front-End Web Dev | PYTHON| JAVA | C | UI-UX | CSE Undergraduate is looking for help.

qa.question: What stage of resume writing are you in?
qa.answer: I need a resume created from scratch

qa.question: Where are you in your career?
Which industries are you focused on?

output.message:
Hello,

I hope this message finds you well. I came across your profile and noticed you’re a Front-End Web Developer with expertise in Python, Java, and UI/UX—currently seeking help with creating a LinkedIn profile resume from scratch. Given your mid-career stage in the technology industry, I’d love to assist you in crafting a resume that highlights your skills and accelerates your job search.

Why Choose My Services?

- Tailored Approach: I’ll customize your resume to showcase your technical expertise and career achievements in the tech space.
- Keyword Optimization: Using industry-specific keywords, I’ll ensure your LinkedIn profile ranks higher in recruiter searches.
- Professional Branding: I’ll help you create a strong personal brand that resonates with tech employers.
- ATS-Friendly Formatting: Your resume will be designed to pass through Applicant Tracking Systems seamlessly.
- Add on Service: 100+ Customized leads (with LinkedIn Id and Email address), with an extra cost, based on your target persona, industry, or company.

What You'll Get:
Customized Resume: A polished, one-page document that captures your achievements, skills, and qualifications tailored to the technology sector.

Pricing and Timeline:
Let’s discuss your specific needs and create a personalized proposal. Feel free to reach out via LinkedIn or email.

Thank you for considering my services. I look forward to helping you elevate your professional presence.

Best regards,
Mayank Agrawal
agrawalmayank26@gmail.com
